results.title: To die - to live: the survivors of Hiroshima
results.creator_credit: Robert Vas and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
By talking with survivors, the bombing of Hiroshima is reconstructed together with dramatic pictures, creating an impression of what it would be like to “live” through an A-bomb experience. Made in collaboration with Prof. Robert Jay Lifton and based on his book “Death in life”.

results.title: Survival of the fastest
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Page, Dick Gilling and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Highlights the evolution of the motorcycle from a primitive machine into a gleaming, glamorous, sophisticated piece of engineering. Scenes at Mallory Park and the 1979 Isle of Man TT follow the fortunes of Barry Sheene, Mike Hailwood and Ron Haslam and their machines. Goes into the research and development, technical and commercial problems, and how Britain and Europe are facing up to the Japanese challenge. Narrated by Tony Britton.

results.title: The Structure of life
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”
A look at Ernst Chain, a volatile and gifted man, who together with Sir Alexander Fleming and Lord Flory, was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1945, for his work on penicillin. He now runs the Biochemistry Department at Imperial College, London. Shows some of the remarkable work now in progress under his direction.

results.title: Square pegs
results.creator_credit: John Mansfield and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Today, applying for a job often means submitting to innumerable tests, not only of ability and intelligence, but also of personality. But just how valid are these tests? This program examines some of the techniques used by the boom industry of Management Selection and follows two candidates through their ordeal.

results.title: The Spike
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Documentary which explains the disease of epilepsy and looks at research which is being done into its causes and how to treat it. Includes extensive interviews with epilepsy sufferers who describe their symptoms and their feelings about the disease and the social stigma attached to it. Presented and narrated by Dr Peter Fenwick.

results.title: Spend and prosper: a portrait of John Maynard Keynes
results.creator_credit: Christopher La Fontaine and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Traces the life of John Maynard Keynes through the eyes of some of the people who knew and worked with him. They include Quentin Bell, J.K. Galbraith and Ninette de Valois. Also spells out some of his economic theories which are in direct opposition to the monetarist policies followed by today’s (1980’s) governments. Narrated by Paul Vaughan.

results.title: The Scientist and the baby
results.creator_credit: Christopher La Fontaine and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
In obstetrics, as in every branch of medicine, research is opening up new avenues of health care. Opposition to the intrusion of science in pregnancy and childbirth is fierce but the medical profession believe that science has proved its case.

results.description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
In obstetrics, as in every branch of medicine, research is opening up new avenues of health care. Opposition to the intrusion of science in pregnancy and childbirth is fierce but the medical profession believe that science has proved its case.

results.title: The Robots are coming
results.creator_credit: Hilary Henson and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
A look at what part robots play in the world today and what research into robot technology is likely to produce in the future. Present day (1970s) robots are used in industry to perform a wide range of tasks considered unsuitable for people because they are dangerous, dirty, or monotonous. They are still fairly simple, with primitive “brains”, but recent research into robot technology could make them far more flexible. Narrated by Paul Vaughan.

results.title: The River that came clean
results.creator_credit: Christopher Riley and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
An environmental success story that begins by emphasising the role of sewage as a major pollutant of the River Thames since the mid 19th century. Shows evidence of the great increase in fish and bird life after a cleaning process was instigated. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
